nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-c-nav__item-label">Citations (292)</div></div></a><a class="nova-legacy-c-nav__item js-lite-click" aria-disabled="false" role="menuitem" href="publication/21571319_Effects_of_Fantasy_Contexts_on_Children&#x27;s_Learning_and_Motivation_Making_Learning_More_Fun#references" data-lite="{&quot;click&quot;:[{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;.js-target-reference&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;st(112)&quot;,&quot;d&quot;:100},{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;.js-target-citationReferences nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-c-nav__item-label">References (59)</div></div></a></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow" aria-hidden="true"><button class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow-trigger"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-e-icon nova-legacy-e-icon--size-s nova-legacy-e-icon--theme-bare nova-legacy-e-icon--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-icon--luminosity-medium"><use class="nova-legacy-c-nav__plus-overflow-trigger" tabindex="-1"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-e-icon nova-legacy-e-icon--size-s nova-legacy-e-icon--theme-bare nova-legacy-e-icon--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-icon--luminosity-medium"><use xlink:href="/m/435227022393349/images/icons/nova/icon-stack-s.svg#ellipsis-s"></use></svg></button></div></div></nav><span role="status"><span><div class="nova-legacy-c-nav__plus-overflow-mount" aria-hidden="true" aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false"></div></span></span></div></div></section></section><div class="nova-legacy-l-flex__item nova-legacy-l-flex nova-legacy-l-flex--gutter-m nova-legacy-l-flex--direction-column@s-up nova-legacy-l-flex--direction-row@xl-only nova-legacy-l-flex--align-items-stretch@s-up nova-legacy-l-flex--justify-content-flex-start@s-up nova-legacy-l-flex--wrap-nowrap@s-up research-detail-middle-section"><div class="nova-legacy-l-flex__item nova-legacy-l-flex__item--grow research-detail-middle-section__item" style="flex-basis:0px;flex-grow:2"><div class="nova-legacy-c-card nova-legacy-c-card--spacing-m nova-legacy-c-card--elevation-1-above"><div class="nova-legacy-c-card__header nova-legacy-c-card__header--show-divider nova-legacy-c-card__header--spacing-inherit"><h2 class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-700">Abstract</h2></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-card__body nova-legacy-c-card__body--spacing-inherit"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-800 research-detail-middle-section__abstract" itemProp="description">Two studies examined the effects of embedding instructional materials in relevant fantasy contexts on children&#x27;s motivation and learning. In Study 1, Ss showed marked preferences for computer-based educational programs that involved fantasy elements. In Study 2, Ss worked with these programs for 5 hr. One program presented purely abstract problems. Others presented identical problems within fantasy contexts. Some Ss chose among 3 fantasies; others were assigned identical fantasies. Tests on the material occurred before, immediately after, and 2 weeks after the experimental sessions. Ss showed significantly greater learning and transfer in the fantasy than in the no-fantasy conditions. Having a choice of fantasies made no difference. Motivational and individualization strategies for enhancing interest and promoting learning are discussed.</div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-l-flex__item nova-legacy-l-flex__item--grow research-detail-middle-section__item" style="flex-basis:0px;flex-grow:1"><div class="lite-page-promo research-detail-signup-promo"><picture class="lite-page-promo__brand (59)</h2></div></div></button></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow" aria-hidden="true"><button class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow-trigger"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-c-nav__plus-overflow-trigger" tabindex="-1"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="nova-legacy-e-icon nova-legacy-e-icon--size-s nova-legacy-e-icon--theme-bare nova-legacy-e-icon--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-icon--luminosity-medium"><use xlink:href="/m/435227022393349/images/icons/nova/icon-stack-s.svg#ellipsis-s"></use></svg></button></div></div></nav><span role="status"><span><div class="nova-legacy-c-nav__plus-overflow-mount" aria-hidden="true" aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false"></div></span></span></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-card__body nova-legacy-c-card__body--spacing-none"><div class="lite-tabs__tab js-target-citations lite-page-visible"><div class="nova-legacy-c-card nova-legacy-c-card--spacing-m nova-legacy-c-card--elevation-1-above publication-citations"><div class="nova-legacy-c-card__body nova-legacy-c-card__body--spacing-none publication-citations__container"><div class="js-target-citation" id="citations"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-m nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside" type="bare"><div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item publication-citations__item publication-citations__item--redesign"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip nova-legacy-c-tooltip--position-above-left nova-legacy-c-tooltip--elevation-none nova-legacy-c-tooltip--color-white nova-legacy-c-tooltip--spacing-m nova-legacy-c-tooltip--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body-content"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... To improve students&#x27; performance in remembering declarative knowledge and enhancing learning effectiveness in the classroom, fantasy elements serve as a powerful tool (Zuo et al., 2023). Incorporating fantasy literature into the curriculum shifts the traditional monotonous teaching-learning process into active, joyful learning <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">(Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992)</mark>. So, fostering imagination and creativity is crucial for preparing children for success in the future in a world that is becoming more complex (Lack &amp; Kumar, 2003).  ...</div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... During the last couple of decades, studies on fantasy have explored how it can be used as a pedagogical tool to encourage students&#x27; engagement in the learning process, to foster creativity and divergent thinking among learners. <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">Parker and Lepper (1992)</mark> demonstrated that fantasy-oriented environments and activities significantly boost children&#x27;s motivation and learning. In an era characterized by rapid technological advancements, hectic social systems, and existential anxieties, fantasy provides a sanctuary where we can immerse ourselves in alternate realities, mythical realms, and epic adventures (Bacon &amp; Charlesford, 2018).  ...</div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... The importance of fantasy in our lives lies in its profound impact on mental, emotional, and social well-being. Research conducted across the globe highlights the multifaceted role of fantasy as a pedagogical tool and as a cognitive, creative, and cultural faculty that shapes various aspects of human experience (Zuo et al., 2023;Shiota &amp; Nomura, 2022;Bunce &amp; Woolley, 2021;Richert &amp;Schlesinger, 2022;<mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992;</mark>Seja &amp; Russ, 1999). The importance of fantasy as a cognitive function essential to emotional regulation has been explored in various studies (Seja &amp; Russ, 1999;Bacon &amp; Charlesford, 2018;Shiota &amp; Nomura, 2022).  ...</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow--body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow-tip"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/392967249_Exploring_Research_Trends_in_Fantasy_as_a_Psychological_Construct_A_Bibliometric_Study_Using_the_Scopus_Database">Exploring Research Trends in Fantasy as a Psychological Construct: A Bibliometric Study Using the Scopus Database</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Article</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-ghost nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Full-text available</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Jun 2025</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Uttam-Das-19" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/11431281507656896-1750348647785_Q64/Uttam-Das-19.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Uttam Kumar Das"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Uttam Kumar Das</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Ananta-Kumar-2316980597" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Ananta Kumar</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-69580555171c8 lite-page-hidden">The present study explores research trends in fantasy by conducting a bibliometric analysis of literature indexed in the Scopus database. The PRISMA framework was employed to identify and select articles from the Scopus database. A search of the Scopus database using the term &quot;fantasy&quot; resulted in 7,177 documents from which 502 articles were shortlisted based on inclusion-exclusion criteria and manual screening. The selected metadata were exported in CSV format and analyzed using the R package Biblioshiny and VOSviewer software for bibliometric analysis and visualization. The study identifies the most influential authors, articles, journals, countries, keywords, and trends in publication over the years. The most cited document was &quot;Brexit Populism and Fantasies of Fulfilment&quot; by Browning, C.S. (2023) with 88 citations, while Personality and Social Psychology emerged as the most influential source with 76 citations. Results show that although the number of publications fluctuated slightly, there has been an exponential overall growth. Research on fantasy as a faculty shows a positive research trend, which will turn it into an emerging research field.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-v-publication-item__action"><span class="nova-legacy-c-button__label">View</span></a></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-button-group__item"><button class="nova-legacy-c-button nova-legacy-c-button--align-center nova-legacy-c-button--radius-m nova-legacy-c-button--size-s nova-legacy-c-button--color-blue nova-legacy-c-button--theme-bare nova-legacy-v-publication-item__action" abstract</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item publication-citations__item publication-citations__item--redesign"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip nova-legacy-c-tooltip--position-above-left nova-legacy-c-tooltip--elevation-none nova-legacy-c-tooltip--color-white nova-legacy-c-tooltip--spacing-m nova-legacy-c-tooltip--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body-content"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... But even if we narrow our focus to only those playful or creative endeavors that do present genuine fantasy (i.e., impossible entities or events), researchers have successfully used fantasy contexts to improve learning. For example, <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">Parker and Lepper (1992)</mark> had children engage in quasi-fantasy adventures (planetary exploration; searching for buried treasure; or playing detective and hunting down criminals) in the context of cognitive-spatial tasks. Children who engaged in a fantasy context reported higher intrinsic motivation and exhibited higher scores on these tasks.  ...</div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... Although <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">Parker and Lepper (1992)</mark> speculated that the relative success of their fantasy contexts was due to increasing interest and motivation (i.e., &quot;fun&quot;), there is a body of recent work suggesting that the fantasy content itself might be beneficial for both adults&#x27; and children&#x27;s reasoning abilities. For example, Weisberg et al. (2015) aimed to teach new vocabulary words to preschool-aged children, presenting half of these children with new words in storybooks that had realistic themes and presenting the other half of the children with new words in storybooks that had fantastical themes.  ...</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow--body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow-tip"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/391930091_From_Hobbits_to_Harry_Potter_A_Psychological_Perspective_on_Fantasy">From Hobbits to Harry Potter: A Psychological Perspective on Fantasy</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-ghost nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Full-text available</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Feb 2025</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Russell-Webster" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/294360290742272-1447192370099_Q64/Russell-Webster.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Russell J Webster"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Russell J Webster</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Deena-Weisberg" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://c5.rgstatic.net/m/4671872220764/images/template/default/profile/profile_default_m.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Deena Skolnick Weisberg"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Deena Skolnick Weisberg</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Donald-Saucier" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/278679541305363-1443453788886_Q64/Donald-Saucier.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Donald A Saucier"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Donald A Saucier</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-69580555173fd lite-page-hidden">Human beings are generally captivated by fantasyâ€”a distinct form of fictionâ€”but there has been relatively little research in the behavioral sciences specifically on this subject (as defined in this article). This article integrates research from different areas of psychology and the humanities to provide a theoretical and methodological foundation from which behavioral scientists can conduct systematic empirical investigations of the relationship between fantasy and diverse psychological phenomena. First, this article establishes a working definition of fantasy, differentiating fantasy from other types of fiction (e.g., horror, science-fiction) and magical thinking/beliefs (e.g., superstition, religion). Second, we review the cognitive bases for creating and engaging with fantasy. Third, we discuss extant research on fantasy in multiple areas of psychology (e.g., learning, clinical/counseling, creativity, terror management) using both child and adult samples, while reviewing key individual differences in fantasy orientation (e.g., fantasy proneness, absorption) and highlighting gaps that require more empirical research. This review illustrates that it is worthwhile to expand research efforts on this construct throughout the behavioral sciences.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... Researchers have shown students have difficulty solving word problems (Bailey, 2002;Hart, 1996;<mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992)</mark>. Reasons offered for this difficulty include: limited student experience with word problems (Bailey, 2002), lack of motivation to solve the word problems (Hart, 1996), and irrelevance of word problems to students&#x27; lives (Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992).  ...</div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... Researchers have shown students have difficulty solving word problems (Bailey, 2002;Hart, 1996;Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992). Reasons offered for this difficulty include: limited student experience with word problems (Bailey, 2002), lack of motivation to solve the word problems (Hart, 1996), and irrelevance of word problems to students&#x27; lives <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">(Parker &amp; Lepper, 1992</mark>). Parker and Lepper state &quot;the need for techniques to enhance student interest in traditional educational materials may actually increase with age&quot; (p.632).  ...</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow--body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow-tip"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/389658434_Elementary_Teachers&#x27;_Perspectives_of_Mathematics_Problem_Solving_Strategies">Elementary Teachers&#x27; Perspectives of Mathematics Problem Solving Strategies</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Article</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">May 2015</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Faye-Bruun-2088268534" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Faye Bruun</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-695805551770a lite-page-hidden">Participants in this study were asked to report what strategies were most often used in their attempts to foster their studentsâ€™ problem solving abilities. Participants included 70 second through fifth-grade elementary teachers from 42 schools in a large state of the south central region in the US. Data analyses of the interviews revealed that none of the educators utilized all problem solving strategies recommended by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. Further examination of the interviews indicated that having their students draw a picture and identify key information was the teachersâ€™ most taught word problem strategy. Here, we provide insight of the reported teachersâ€™ strategies and the need for more explicit instruction of problem solving strategies when educating mathematics teachers.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text Motivasyonla baÄŸlantÄ±lÄ± diÄŸer bir konu da eÄŸitim ve Ã¶ÄŸretim sÃ¼recinin daha eÄŸlenceli bir hale getirilmesidir. olmasÄ±nÄ± saÄŸlamaktadÄ±r <mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">(Parker, 1992</mark> (Skinner &amp; Belmont, 1993 (Lepper &amp; Chabay, 1985): class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow-tip"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/394443365_Turk_dili_ve_edebiyati_ogretiminde_disiplinler_arasi_yaklasimla_materyal_gelistirme_Divan_siiri_ornegi_Developing_materials_with_an_interdisciplinary_approach_in_teaching_turkish_language_and_literatu">TÃ¼rk dili ve edebiyatÄ± Ã¶ÄŸretiminde disiplinler arasÄ± yaklaÅŸÄ±mla materyal geliÅŸtirme: Divan ÅŸiiri Ã¶rneÄŸi / Developing materials with an interdisciplinary approach in teaching turkish language and literature: A case study of Divan poetry</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Thesis</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-ghost nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Full-text available</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Oct 2024</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Oya-Uysal-4" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/11431281585566070-1754982898390_Q64/Oya-Uysal-4.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Oya Uysal"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Oya Uysal</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-6958055516f2a lite-page-hidden">It is expected that this research will create a new perspective in introducing, conveying, and instilling aesthetic appreciation for the form and content characteristics of divan poetry to students. This aim is expected to be realized through learning environments where material examples developed with an interdisciplinary approach serve in the teaching of Divan poetry in Turkish language and literature. In the research, using an interdisciplinary approach, example materials were created by relating divan poetry texts from Turkish literatureâ€”suitable for the secondary education levelâ€”to other relevant disciplines. It is thought that the created materials will serve as an example for future materials to be supported by appropriate teaching methods and techniques. In the learning environments served by the material examples prepared with an interdisciplinary approach, it is expected that students will not feel limited by the thinking patterns of a specific discipline and will subsequently see information and experiences from different disciplines within certain concepts, thereby: â€¢ gaining critical and creative thinking skills, â€¢ developing problem-solving and independent decision-making abilities, â€¢ achieving easier, more permanent, meaningful, willing, confident, and efficient learning, â€¢ gaining an interdisciplinary perspective to achieve the goals of the environment or overcome encountered problems, â€¢ realizing the expected learning objectives at the end of the learning and teaching process. The research is qualitative and employs a descriptive survey model. To achieve the aims and sub-aims of the research, relevant publications and studies were reviewed, and the obtained data were analyzed using a descriptive and interpretative technique. With the obtained data, materials were prepared for the Turkish language and literature course on divan poetry using an interdisciplinary approach. With these materials, it is aimed to arouse interest in divan literature among today&#x27;s students, to introduce them to the richness of genres and forms in divan literature, the subtle imagination, linguistic skill, and intellectual horizon, to make them aware of the traditional expression forms, and the richness of topics and content, and to enable students with a tendency towards literary taste in this direction to discover themselves. The study, which includes theoretical information, designed materials, and the stages and interpretations of the process of implementing these materials, also contains suggestions for relevant researchers and educators to serve as examples for similar studies. It is planned for the study to be transformed into an experimental study in the future.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-o-pack--vertical-align-middle"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-button-group"><div class="nova-legacy-c-button-group nova-legacy-c-button-group--gutter-m nova-legacy-c-button-group--orientation-horizontal nova-legacy-c-button-group--width-auto nova-legacy-v-publication-item__actions"><div class="nova-legacy-c-button-group__item"><a href="publication/394443365_Turk_dili_ve_edebiyati_ogretiminde_disiplinler_arasi_yaklasimla_materyal_gelistirme_Divan_siiri_ornegi_Developing_materials_with_an_interdisciplinary_approach_in_teaching_turkish_language_and_literatu" class="nova-legacy-c-button nova-legacy-c-button--align-center nova-legacy-c-button--radius-m nova-legacy-c-button--size-s nova-legacy-c-button--color-blue nova-legacy-c-button--theme-bare nova-legacy-v-publication-item__action"><span class="nova-legacy-c-button__label">View</span></a></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-button-group__item"><button class="nova-legacy-c-button nova-legacy-c-button--align-center nova-legacy-c-button--radius-m nova-legacy-c-button--size-s nova-legacy-c-button--color-blue nova-legacy-c-button--theme-bare nova-legacy-v-publication-item__action" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-c-button__label"><span class=" js-lite-click" data-lite="{&quot;click&quot;:[{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;.js-target-abstract-6958055516f2a&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;tc(lite-page-hidden)&quot;},{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;self&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;tc(lite-page-hidden)&quot;}]}">Show abstract</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item publication-citations__item publication-citations__item--redesign"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip nova-legacy-c-tooltip--position-above-left nova-legacy-c-tooltip--elevation-none nova-legacy-c-tooltip--color-white nova-legacy-c-tooltip--spacing-m nova-legacy-c-tooltip--luminosity-medium nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__body-content"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack nova-legacy-o-stack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-stack--spacing-none nova-legacy-o-stack--show-divider nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-body">... Later studies have demonstrated the positive effect of Malone and Lepper&#x27;s strategies on students&#x27; intrinsic motivation and conceptual understanding [61,<mark class="nova-legacy-e-text-highlight nova-legacy-e-text-highlight--color-yellow">62]</mark>.  ...</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow--body"><div class="nova-legacy-c-tooltip__arrow-tip"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/391270256_What_makes_digital_learning_effective_Evaluation_of_a_digital_learning_module_about_positron_emission_tomography">What makes digital learning effective? Evaluation of a digital learning module about positron emission tomography</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Sarah ZÃ¶chling</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Tobias-Fredlund-2" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://c5.rgstatic.net/m/4671872220764/images/template/default/profile/profile_default_m.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Tobias Fredlund"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Tobias Fredlund</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-6958055517586 lite-page-hidden">Following the global COVID-19 pandemic, digital learning environments have gained in importance in education all around the world. A new digital learning format called a â€œDigital Learning Moduleâ€ (DLM) was developed within the Physics Education Research (PER) group at CERN, consisting of a series of prerecorded explanatory and experiment videos, interactive elements, an interactive simulation experiment, and expert interviews. So far, one DLM has been created on the topic of positron emission tomography (PET). Aiming to establish a set of effective design principles that can be employed in the design of future DLMs or similar digital learning environments, the goal of this research is to evaluate the already existing PET DLM. In doing so, this research brings together different theoretical and empirical studies, in order to identify design principles fitting the format of the DLM. It also reviews key physics literature on PET to identify its disciplinary-relevant aspects. First, an analysis of the PET DLM was performed in terms of the identified design principles and disciplinary-relevant aspects. Then, nine semistructured interviews were conducted with high-school students from Greece and Austria as they worked through the PET DLM. A qualitative content analysis of the interview transcripts has determined the set of effective design principles that will constitute the foundation of future DLMs developed by the CERN PER group and can serve as a starting point and reference for researchers developing similar digital learning environments elsewhere.

Published by the American Physical Society 2025</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-o-pack--vertical-align-middle"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack__item href="publication/398548330_Developing_an_Electronic_Game_for_Vocabulary_Learning_A_Case_Study">Developing an Electronic Game for Vocabulary Learning: A Case Study</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Chapter</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Mar 2011</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Michael-L-Kamil-2333475935" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Michael L. Kamil</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Cheryl-Taitague-2025089190" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Cheryl Taitague</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-6958055516eab lite-page-hidden">There is intense interest in computer games. A total of 65 percent of all American households play computer games, and sales of such games increased 22.9 percent last year. The average amount of game playing time was found to be 13.2 hours per week. The popularity and market success of games is evident from both the increased earnings from games, over $7 Billion in 2005, and from the fact that over 200 academic institutions worldwide now offer game related programs of study.In view of the intense interest in computer games educators and trainers, in business, industry, the government, and the military would like to use computer games to improve the delivery of instruction. Computer Games and Instruction is intended for these educators and trainers. It reviews the research evidence supporting use of computer games, for instruction, and also reviews the history of games in general, in education, and by the military. In addition chapters examine gender differences in game use, and the implications of games for use by lower socio-economic students, for studentsâ€™ reading, and for contemporary theories of instruction. Finally, well known scholars of games will respond to the evidence reviewed.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-o-pack--vertical-align-middle"><div nova-legacy-o-stack--no-gutter-outside"><div class="nova-legacy-o-stack__item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-citation-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/393955693_Using_ChatGPT_to_bring_non-player_characters_to_life_Effects_on_students&#x27;_storyline-driven_game-based_writing_learning">Using ChatGPT to bring non-player characters to life: Effects on studentsâ€™ storyline-driven game-based writing learning</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Article</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Jul 2025</span></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">COMPUT EDUC</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Ya-Xiao" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/11431281218364897-1705582191788_Q64/Ya-Xiao.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Ya Xiao"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Ya Xiao</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Danling-Li" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/833034890772480-1575622403654_Q64/Danling-Li.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Danling Li"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Danling Li</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kai-Guo-4" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/11431281223211345-1707650835392_Q64/Kai-Guo-4.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Kai Guo"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Kai Guo</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-6958055516fe6 lite-page-hidden">This study introduces a novel design approach to game-based learning by integrating ChatGPT into the development of non-player characters (NPCs) within storylines. This integration seeks to enhance interactivity with student players and foster an immersive, dynamic learning environment. We applied this approach in English as a Foreign Language (EFL) writing classrooms to examine its impact on both the affective and cognitive aspects of student writing learning, as well as their writing performance. Utilizing a quasi-experimental design, the study involved two classes of Chinese undergraduate students. One class (n = 42) engaged with ChatGPT-powered NPCs, while the other class (n = 43) interacted with conventional NPCs in a storyline-based game designed to enhance argumentative writing skills. Quantitative data were collected through questionnaires assessing studentsâ€™ intrinsic motivation, situational interest, cognitive load, and effort regulation. Additionally, student essays were evaluated to compare writing performance across the two conditions. Qualitative data, including studentsâ€™ chat histories with ChatGPT-powered NPCs, were gathered to investigate their interactions. The results indicated that engaging with ChatGPT-enhanced NPCs positively influenced studentsâ€™ intrinsic motivation and situational interest, leading them to invest greater effort in completing learning tasks. Notably, interactions with ChatGPT-enhanced NPCs did not increase studentsâ€™ cognitive load during the learning process. Moreover, students who interacted with ChatGPT-powered NPCs exhibited superior writing performance, producing essays that were significantly clearer, more elaborated, and more persuasive, while also more effectively addressing opposing viewpoints. Additionally, students employed various conversational strategies while interacting with these NPCs. This study not only advances our understanding of the role of generative artificial intelligence in educational contexts but also provides valuable insights for educators seeking to enhance student engagement and learning outcomes through innovative instructional strategies.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-o-pack--vertical-align-middle"><div class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Carole Ames</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-695805551803d lite-page-hidden">Investigated whether competitive and individualistic goal structures elicit achievement cognitions that have been associated with helpless vs mastery-oriented children, respectively. 88 5th- and 6th-grade children were administered a novel achievement task in which a high vs low performance outcome was manipulated by varying the number of solvable puzzles across 2 sets of 6 puzzles, within either a competitive or individual goal structure. A &quot;thought-matching&quot; methodology was used to assess the type of frequency of Ss&#x27; thoughts. Results revealed that Ss made more ability attributions in the competitive than in the individual condition. In the individual condition, Ss displayed a mastery orientation in that they made more effort attributions and engaged in self-instructions and self-monitoring more than did Ss in the competitive condition. Ability attributions were predictive of Ss&#x27; positive and negative affective reactions. Results suggest that Ss were thinking about responses to the question &quot;Was I smart?&quot; in the competitive setting but were thinking about &quot;How can I do this task?&quot; in the individual setting. It is suggested that getting children to think about how to improve their performance may not be compatible with the focus of attention in competitive situations. (29 ref)</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack class="nova-legacy-c-button-group nova-legacy-c-button-group--gutter-m nova-legacy-c-button-group--orientation-horizontal nova-legacy-c-button-group--width-auto class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-reference-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/309528056_Children&#x27;s_Beliefs_in_Their_Own_Control_of_Reinforcements_in_Intellectual-Academic_Achievement_Situations">Children&#x27;s Beliefs in Their Own Control of Reinforcements in Intellectual-Academic Achievement Situations</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Article</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Mar 1965</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Virginia-C-Crandall-2034799812" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Virginia C. Crandall</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Walter-Katkovsky-2181097" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Walter Katkovsky</span></span></a></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Vaughn-J-Crandall-1757819" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Vaughn J. Crandall</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-6958055518028 lite-page-hidden">This study describes a scale for assessing children&#x27;s beliefs that they, rather than other people, are responsible for their intellectual-academic successes and failures. Subscale scores assessing responsibility for successes and for failures were generally independent of each other. Split-half and test-retest reliabilities were moderately high. Normative data on 923 Ss in grades 3-12 indicate that self-responsibility is already established by third grade, that older girls give more self-responsible answers than older boys, and that slight but significant age changes occur in subscale scores dependent upon the sex of the child. Responsibility scores were moderately related to intelligence, ordinal position, and size of family, and inconsistently related to social class. Evidence of prediction to intellectual-achievement performance is presented.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div An introduction</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span Farr</span></span></a></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack class="nova-legacy-c-button-group nova-legacy-c-button-group--gutter-m nova-legacy-c-button-group--orientation-horizontal nova-legacy-c-button-group--width-auto class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none class="nova-legacy-v-citation-item__context-source"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item nova-legacy-v-publication-item--size-m gtm-reference-item"><div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack--gutter-m"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/263464504_Cognition_in_Practice">Cognition in Practice</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Book</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Jul 1988</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__person-list"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jean-Lave" type="button"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/534531105329152-1504453554402_Q64/Jean-Lave.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Jean Lave"/></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Jean Lave</span></span></a></li></ul></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-69580555185e6 lite-page-hidden">Most previous research on human cognition has focused on problem-solving, and has confined its investigations to the laboratory. As a result, it has been difficult to account for complex mental processes and their place in culture and history. In this startling - indeed, disco in forting - study, Jean Lave moves the analysis of one particular form of cognitive activity, - arithmetic problem-solving - out of the laboratory into the domain of everyday life. In so doing, she shows how mathematics in the &#x27;real world&#x27;, like all thinking, is shaped by the dynamic encounter between the culturally endowed mind and its total context, a subtle interaction that shapes 1) Both tile human subject and the world within which it acts. The study is focused on mundane daily, activities, such as grocery shopping for &#x27;best buys&#x27; in the supermarket, dieting, and so on. Innovative in its method, fascinating in its findings, the research is above all significant in its theoretical contributions. Have offers a cogent critique of conventional cognitive theory, turning for an alternative to recent social theory, and weaving a compelling synthesis from elements of culture theory, theories of practice, and Marxist discourse. The result is a new way of understanding human thought processes, a vision of cognition as the dialectic between persons-acting, and the settings in which their activity is constituted. The book will appeal to anthropologists, for its novel theory of the relation of cognition to culture and context; to cognitive scientists and educational theorists; and to the &#x27;plain folks&#x27; who form its subject, and who will recognize themselves in it, a rare accomplishment in the modern social sciences.</span></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__footer-actions"><div class="nova-legacy-o-pack nova-legacy-o-pack--gutter-m nova-legacy-o-pack--width-auto nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-2 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="publication/262187490_Mathematical_Problem_Solving">Mathematical Problem Solving</a></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta"><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-left"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-block nova-legacy-e-badge--luminosity-high nova-legacy-e-badge--size-l nova-legacy-e-badge--theme-solid nova-legacy-e-badge--radius-m nova-legacy-v-publication-item__badge">Book</span></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-right"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item nova-legacy-v-publication-item__meta-data-item"><span class="">Jan 1985</span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-none class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare gtm-recommendation-item-link" href="publication/234656103_Computer_Programming_Experience_and_Mathematical_Problem_Solving">Computer Programming Experience and Mathematical Problem Solving</a></h3><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span>September 1989</span> Â· <span>Journal of Research on Computing in Education</span></div><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-auto"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Leah-P-McCoy-2130875977" type="button">Leah P. McCoy</a></span></span></li><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Norman-R-Dodl-2127754846" type="button">Norman R. Dodl</a></span></span></li></ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">A path model was constructed to illustrate the hypothesized causal relationship among experience in computer programming, mathematical problem solving, and other relevant variables. The model was tested with a sample of 800 high school students. Results indicated that ability had the largest causal effect on mathematical problem solving achievement. However, three variables had a moderate effect: <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite="{&quot;click&quot;:[{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;.js-target-6958055518b97&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;tc(lite-page-hidden)&quot;},{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;self&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;ac(lite-page-hidden)&quot;}]}">... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-6958055518b97"> computer programming experience, mathematics experience, and gender. The conclusion was that there was evidence to support the theory of transfer of skills from computer programming experience to mathematical problem solving.</span></div><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent publication-recommendation-item__more" href="publication/234656103_Computer_Programming_Experience_and_Mathematical_Problem_Solving">Read more</a></div></div></div></div><div class="nova-legacy-o-grid__column class="nova-legacy-c-card__body nova-legacy-c-card__body--spacing-inherit"><div class="publication-recommendation-item"><div class="nova-legacy-l-flex__item nova-legacy-l-flex publication-recommendation-item__item-badges"><div class="nova-legacy-l-flex__item"><span class="nova-legacy-e-badge nova-legacy-e-badge--color-green nova-legacy-e-badge--display-inline nova-legacy-e-text--size-l nova-legacy-e-text--family-display nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit publication-recommendation-item__title"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span>November 2011</span></div><ul class="nova-legacy-e-list nova-legacy-e-list--size-m nova-legacy-e-list--type-inline nova-legacy-e-list--spacing-auto"><li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Ty-Lim-2057095695" type="button">Ty Lim</a></span></span></li></ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">A NOR-type split gate embedded Flash memory product program marginal fail with odd/even word line failure pattern. Base on cell current comparison, programming cycling tests and voltage drop measurements, the invisible cause of even/odd cells weak program failure mechanism was verified and confirmed visibly by cross sectioning and junction stain treatment. This problem was then solved by <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite="{&quot;click&quot;:[{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;.js-target-6958055518e34&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;tc(lite-page-hidden)&quot;},{&quot;t&quot;:&quot;self&quot;,&quot;a&quot;:&quot;ac(lite-page-hidden)&quot;}]}">... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-6958055518e34"> tightening photo alignment control and exposure conditions.</span></div><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent publication-recommendation-item__more" href="publication/267516982_Split-Gate_Flash_Memory_Cell_OddEven_Fail_Pattern_Failure_Analysis">Read more</a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div (59)</div></div></a></div><div class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow" aria-hidden="true"><button class="nova-legacy-c-nav__scroll-overflow-trigger"><svg aria-hidden="true"
